UNSW students enrol in this course at the relevant PLuS Alliance partner university. Please visit PLuS Alliance website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"YCAN8000 - US Cyber Policy and Information Security","description":"

This course will be taught by Arizona State University as part of the PLuS Alliance.
The course will be taught fully online.


ASU Course Code: CPP 591


The course prepares students to understand and manage human and technical resources within the increasingly important cyber and information security domains with a substantive focus on these issues within the United States governance system. As high-profile data breaches and cyber attacks – that result in physical losses, disruptions, and disasters -- impose greater risks and costs on our public and private sector - as well as military and intelligence - networks, the policy and management aspects of these challenges have come to the fore. Compounding the technical and operational challenges arising from the protection of operating systems, networking, and systems administration, managers and Chief Technology/Risk/Security/Data/Information Officers face a multi-dimensional set of political risks, including how to effectively manage data content and evaluation, information veracity, and information sharing and distribution.


Further course information can be found here. (insert weblink to ASU course catalogue)

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"67b1e49cdb7dfc90be4672f5f396193c","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment Essays","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

During the first four weeks of the term students will be asked to write two short essays in response to assigned reading materials. The purpose of these assigned short essays is twofold: (1) it assists students in become more familiar with key foundational concepts, (2) it is designed for the student to become more skilled in brief writing tasks that require that assessment of conceptual material (typically possessing critical policy, planning, management and operational importance) be conveyed with an economy of language that is accessible to a generalist audience.

\n

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"27b1e49cdb7dfc90be4672f5f396193d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2fb1e49cdb7dfc90be4672f5f396193c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"27b1e49cdb7dfc90be4672f5f3961940","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

The course will close with a written final exam which will be comprehensive in nature. The exam will be an individual effort with no exceptions.  In no way shape or form should will it be permissible to discuss any aspect of the exam with anyone else; neither classmates nor anyone else should be consulted while students complete the exam.  Consulting assigned reading materials, PPT slides, and class discussion materials is both permissible and expected; however, conducting web or other informational searches are not acceptable.  The exam will be designed as a means of testing overall comprehension of key concepts and issues covered during the term, and as a check on course learning objectives being met.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"27b1e49cdb7dfc90be4672f5f396193d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"27b1e49cdb7dfc90be4672f5f396193e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2fb1e49cdb7dfc90be4672f5f396193c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2fb1e49cdb7dfc90be4672f5f396193d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3bb1e49cdb7dfc90be4672f5f3961958","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online Discussion Sessions","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Each student in the course will participate in three designated discussion sessions, which will pertain to assigned reading materials, video, or other similar materials provided. To receive maximum credit for participation, students will be asked to provide an original responses to discussion topics that are provided, as well as responding meaningfully to other students’ responses

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"27b1e49cdb7dfc90be4672f5f396193d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2fb1e49cdb7dfc90be4672f5f396193d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"77b1e49cdb7dfc90be4672f5f3961950","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"?\tProgram, Process or Policy Assessment Paper","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Producing a more in-depth analytic paper than the short essays is an opportunity for students to examine and analyze community programmatic and policymaking actions in practice in order to understand hazards governance overall. The details on this assignment will be provided in the first half of the term. It will entail selection of a hazards-relevant program (e.g. a community climate adaptation strategy), process (e.g. a local Threat, Hazards Identification Risk Assessment process) or policy (e.g. local land-use ordinances pertaining to hazard mitigation) for analysis using key concepts covered in the course.
